body:
# Apple Wallet Suica vs New Welcome Suica Mobile

Traveling to Japan soon and trying to figure out which one we'd be better off using. So far, the only difference I see is that the new mobile app let's me buy a 1-day pass for Tokyo while the Apple Wallet Suica is a simple top up and go. Am I missing something?

Hey! Not sure if this is the right place to ask. I'm planning to get a JR Kansai-Hiroshima area pass for my trip between Osaka, Kyoto, Hiroshima and Nara. But I'm arriving to Osaka from Hakone, and from what I read, Shinkansen Odawara to Shin-Osaka is covered by the pass. But I'm not sure if I can exchange my pass at Odawara station and if I need to do so. I will appreciate any advice, also on the best way to get from Hakone to Osaka.
Does anyone have any recommendations for Golf Courses near Sapporo that is tourist friendly?

I'm looking to do a trip down to Fukuoka/Kyushu in November.  The trip will start and end in Tokyo, but searching for options on how best to get from Tokyo to Fukuoka.  The way back will likely be via the Shinkansen as we will make a few stops along the way - but getting there in the first place is the challenge.

Specifically, there are a few ways to make this trip - train, ferry, or airplane.  The difficulty being that I can't seem to find how to book a flight from Haneda to FUK (or how to pre-book ferries).  I would take any or all advice on this!
Anybody know how to by pass “3D Secure” authentication on SmartEX? Trying to book Shinkansen tickets but it keeps giving me an error. My bank isn’t able to help.
Do I need JESTA when visiting japan? I just watched a Youtube video, about how it was recently passed as of March.

Okay a few questions about arrival tasks: 

1. We are landing at Kansai International Airport. As English only speakers will it be easy to find a 7/11 atm to get cash out,  the counter to buy IC cards at and the airport limousine counter to buy tickets? Are there English signs in airports?

2. Do we need cash to purchase IC cards or can we pay by card? (We have android phones so need physical cards) 

3. How much yen should we get out of the atm on arrival? There are 4 of us but we'll use credit cards for payments whenever possible on our trip.

4. We are planning to collect eki stamps in our stamp books, and have read that other places of significance also sometimes have them, not just trains. Does anyone know if thr airports have a special stamp too?

Thanks!

Hi Guys! It's my first time visiting Japan, looking for feedback on general locations! Going for two weeks.

I'm going in early June and was planning on spending 7 days, 6 nights in Tokyo. After that, one night at a ryokan in Kawaguchiko before moving onto Osaka for 5 nights. During my time in Osaka, I wanted to take a day trip to Hiroshima to check out the Atomic Dome, go another day really early in the morning to check out Himeji Castle and maybe check out Kobe on the way back, unless you guys have suggestions. Then, a day trip to Kyoto.

I would be heading back to Tokyo for the last day before flying out.

Is this too many cities/places to pack in during a two week visit? Pointers are appreciated!

Asking for a friend currently. They just got denied a rental car, and we're unsure why.

They are in Japan for around 9 months, has a translation of their license. And has been using it. It's about 7 months in now. But they got told by rental company it's not valid suddenly? 

They seemed to be pointing to the three month rule. Which I thought only meant that the twelve month validity did not reset for shorter trips, eg. first entry still counts as starting point, to stop people from "renewing" their twelve-month period by leaving and returning quickly.

Is it really true that the original validity period of twelve months just is cut short and made invalid in it's entirety as well? Eg. for the remaining X months.

Meds question

My standard travel kit is always

1. ibuprofen
2. Paracetamol
3. Loperamide
4. Loratadine
5. Melatonin (3mg)

Now according to the list of the ministry none of this is prohibited, I think, but when I google I get a lot of mixed information on melatonin.  I wouldn't be bringing massive amounts of these into the country, 15 of each tops.

Can someone please enlighten me?

Hello, I'm planning a trip to Japan for the 3 weeks in the beginning of october.
Currently these are my plans for where to go and the amount of days I'll stay in each city.
Arrive in Tokyo and stay there for 2 nights
Fly to Sapporo and stay there for 5 nights
Fly to Kyoto and stay there for 8 nights
Get the Shinkansen and go back to Tokyo for the remainder of the days

I have a few questions that I hope some of you can answer.
Is it rainy in Japan (mostly concernd about Sapporo) in october?
Are the excursions from Sapporo to the bluepond/geysers/Mount Yōtei available around the date that I'm there?


To keep my expenses on the lower side I want to go to capsule hotels do you have recommendations for places to stay?
If you got some extra recommendations about excursions or something else, please let me know :-).

Sorry if my english is bad.
Thank you for reading and the replies! :-)

Looking to travel to Japan in November.  Was looking at a travel agency, but it's more expensive than I want to afford.  Especially after signing up for classes.

Looking for advice on how to do this for 2 weeks.
[removed]

The tourist app is very new, but for normal tourists, it probably makes more sense than getting the regular card via Apple Wallet now. Note the card is only valid for 180 days. Not a big deal ultimately, and the app is intended to make it easier for tourists to do things like attach special passes to the card.

Also note that having the Welcome Suica app entitles you to some discounts/specials at places throughout the country.

The regular Suica is intended for normal commuters, and it doesn't expire. You can also the passes you're talking about to the regular Suica via the Suica app, but that app is entirely in Japanese.

Where did you read that? Odawara is nowhere near Kansai. That pass only covers the Shinkansen southbound from Osaka, and the coverage of non-shinkansen trains falls way short of Odawara by several hundred km.
https://www.westjr.co.jp/global/en/ticket/pass/kansai_hiroshima/

You book the flight like any other flight. I booked ANA out of Haneda to Kagoshima airport for my trip next month. You can easily book to Fukuoka from Haneda, just load up google flights, who flies there, then go to their site and book.

This heavily affects Visa cards and your bank won’t be able to do anything. Mastercard and Amex are usually OK.

Alternatively, use the JR West site.

It’s not going to be in place until 2030: [https://www.news.com.au/travel/destinations/asia/major-change-for-tourists-visiting-japan/news-story/3f3cda0f5ac2edbd4fe218f199df2f4e](https://www.news.com.au/travel/destinations/asia/major-change-for-tourists-visiting-japan/news-story/3f3cda0f5ac2edbd4fe218f199df2f4e)
There’s English language signage throughout airports and train stations in Japan.

Q1 You'll have plenty of English signs, and often even English speaking staff at major transport hubs in all the large cities.

Q2 There are machines where you might be able to buy an IC card with credit card, but I'm not sure about Osaka airport. Most require cash, and you'll definitely need cash for any top ups anyway.

Q3 Hard to say without any details of your trip. For our family of 3, our most recent trips needed less than 100k yen for a 2 weeks, mainly in the larger cities.
I'd suggest staying overnight in Hiroshima and visiting Himeji on your way there or back. There's lots to see in Hiroshima. Kobe looks pretty uninteresting compared to Osaka and Hiroshima.

Yes, you can travel more cheaply if you organise everything yourself. And it's not hard; pretty much everyone on the sub is an independent traveller.

How much can you afford and what do you intend to do? It is still an international holiday so you will still spend what most people consider a large amount of money.

Doing classes and organised tours always add a lot to the cost of travel.

Japan is an advanced economy, so the overall costs of visiting are going to be substantial even if you’re from a country with a good exchange rate.

You can save money by organising things yourself, skipping tours and the like and limiting how much you travel between cities. Business hotel chains can provide good value accommodation, but expect tiny rooms. If you’re on a tight budget hostels might be an option.

There are a bunch of guides available - I'd personally start with [japan-guide.com](http://japan-guide.com) and look at their recommended itineraries. You can easily spend less than $7,000 (or even $5,000) for the month planning it yourself. It can feel overwhelming to start, but there's a lot of help out there for Japan.

Something I like to do when I have free time is look at a city on Google Maps and select its "attractions" filter to see what's out there. I save everything to a list and then use what I saved when I'm actually there to figure out what I want to do of a day.
Just look at an example itinerary and book it yourself. I find this was half the price. Obviously it takes more of your time, that's why it costs more to pay an agency to do it for you.
